title: Meir Ashkenazi (merchant)
text:
Meir Ashkenazi was a sixteenth-century <a href="Crimea">Crimea</a>n <a href="Jew">Jew</a>.
An <a href="diplomat">envoy</a> of the <a href="Crimean%20Khanate">Khan of Crimea</a> in the sixteenth century, Ashkenazi was killed by <a href="pirates">pirates</a> on a voyage from <a href="Gava%2C%20Italy">Gava</a> (near <a href="Genoa">Genoa</a>) to <a href="Dakhel">Dakhel</a> (probably Dakhel or Dakleh in the western oasis of <a href="Upper%20Egypt">Upper Egypt</a>), between the 15th and the 25th day of <a href="Tammuz%20%28Hebrew%20month%29">Tammuz</a> (July), 1567. From the testimony of the witness Elias ben Nehemiah, given before the board of rabbis in <a href="Safed">Safed</a> in the case of the widow and heirs of the slain Meïr Ashkenazi, it was made evident that he was an inhabitant of <a href="Kefe">Kefe</a>; that his parents were still living there; that he had a brother who was a student in the "<a href="yeshiva">yeshiva</a>" of <a href="Brest-Litovsk">Brest-Litovsk</a>; that he had brought to Gava prisoners of war from Egypt; that he was appointed envoy of the "<a href="Khan%20%28title%29">khan</a>" of the <a href="Tatars">Tatars</a> to the king of <a href="Poland">Poland</a>; and that on the way from Gava to Dakhel he was slain by pirates with all the passengers on the ship.
